ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Professor Berger compiled a satisfactory syllabus that included writings about animals across time, genre, and place. I gained a lot of insights from my own analysis of the readings, as well as through conversations with Professor Berger. However, the course seminar was not constructive, and Professor Berger did not facilitate discussion but instead dominated it.
A really broad overview of literature. The name is misleading though, as the texts were very diverse.

I ultimately found that the essays this course asked me to write provided an opportunity for me to explore in greater depth topics that interested me, but I felt that I frequently  had to bring in outside knowledge and experience to get anything out of the readings. I dont feel that I developed any new skills or insights in this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course could be improved through better seminar facilitation. Clear and relevant discussion questions, time for each student to speak without interruption or soliloquy from the professor, and clear guidance from the professor when the conversation strays would make the course better. The course assessments were a strength, being flexible and instructive.
Really great course, good readings, kind professor who cares and is clearly quite very smart.

This course really suffered from a lack of overarching direction. After taking this course, I couldnt see a central theme that connected all of the readings and discussions. I thought the work and readings we did before spring break clearly connected, but I wasnt sure how the readings during the last 1/3 of the semester connected to the earlier ones at all.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The course's value seems to depend on the group of students taking it, as well as how they interact with Professor Berger. I don't particularly recommend the course, since the amount I learned compared to the amount of time I felt annoyed by how little we were learning or discussing was not sufficient.
Yes I would for people in the major. He can be a tough grader, but overall good course.

I would not recommend this course to another student. The course was poorly organized, and especially during the second half of the semester it was unclear, even after a 2 hour discussion, how some of the readings connected to any of the others. This course was also hamstrung by the low enrollment this year: a 2 hour seminar with only 7 students is a stretch. I thought professor Berger did an outstanding job filling in the silences that arose, but the discussion was often strained and frequently centered on tangents to vaguely related topics and books we hadnt read for class.

extras.title: AMST 358 01/ENGL 281 01 - Animals in Modrn Amer Fiction
